name: Pet Shelter System
description: Build a pet shelter management system using classes! You'll create a Pet class to represent animals in a shelter, then extend it with inheritance to create a Dog class with special behaviors. This project demonstrates how classes help organize real-world data (like pet information) and how inheritance lets us create specialized versions of classes.
learning_goals: Create a class with __init__ to initialize object properties
Define methods that use self to access object data
Use inheritance to extend a parent class
Override parent methods in child classes
Create and interact with multiple objects

steps.instruction: Create a class called Pet with an __init__ method that takes three parameters: self, name, and age. Inside __init__, assign name to self.name and age to self.age.
steps.hint: Use def __init__(self, name, age): and then set self.name = name and self.age = age

steps.instruction: Add a method called info to the Pet class. It should take self as a parameter and use print() to display the pet's name and age in this exact format: "Name: [name], Age: [age]". Make sure to use the exact format shown.
steps.hint: Define the method inside the Pet class with proper indentation. Use self.name and self.age to access the attributes.

steps.instruction: Create a Dog class that inherits from Pet. Use pass as the body for now (we'll add more in the next step).
steps.hint: Use class Dog(Pet): to create a child class that inherits from Pet.

steps.instruction: Remove the pass statement from the Dog class and add a method called bark. It should take self as a parameter and use print() to display exactly: "Woof! I am [name]!" (use self.name for the name).
steps.hint: The bark method should use self.name to access the dog's name that was set by the parent Pet class.

steps.instruction: Create a Dog object with the name "Buddy" and age 3, and store it in a variable called my_dog. Then call the info method on my_dog.
steps.hint: Use my_dog = Dog("Buddy", 3) to create the object, then call my_dog.info()

steps.instruction: Call the bark method on my_dog. Then create another Pet object (not Dog) with the name "Whiskers" and age 2, store it in a variable called my_cat, and call the info method on my_cat.
steps.hint: Call my_dog.bark() first. Then create a Pet object with my_cat = Pet("Whiskers", 2) and call my_cat.info()
steps.expected_output:
Name: Buddy, Age: 3
Woof! I am Buddy!
Name: Whiskers, Age: 2
